Google Spreadsheets

  1. We use a google docs spreadsheet at initial planning and prioritization with product owners but that's as technical as it gets. When development has started we use homegrown story cards and post-its for our visible workspace and Redmine for bug tracking (and maybe the wiki functionality for documentation). (LinkedIn3)
  2. For a team distributed over three continents (America, Europe and Asia): Excel spreadshet containing both product and sprint backlog, with some easy feauteres to mark what sprint a story/task belongs to. It only worked using the shared workbook feature because the teams shared the file system. Now I'm currently setting up Scrum for a number of teams distributed in two European companies not (easily) sharing the same filesystem - and are inclined to use the same template but converted to Google Spreadsheet. Anyway, my company is using GoogleDocs as Office system. (LinkedIn3)
  3. Google spreadsheets. Many of you will argue: “no way to link user stories, no way to link product backlog and spring backlog…”. I know, I know. However this approach has been proved. I found nothing better than Google docs from collaboration and simplicity point of view. People over processes and tools, remember? (LinkedIn2)
  4. We've used a Google Spreadsheet for a taskboard - but, I guess, only if you have a distributed team. You get the burndown chart automatically if you set it up right. (mobi)
